questions.question_text:
User A is a Basic License holder. User B is a Business License holder. These two users, along with many additional users, are in the same organizational unit at the same company. When User A attempts to access Drive, they receive the following error: "We are sorry, but you do not have access to Google Docs Editors.
Please contact your Organization Administrator for access." User B is not presented with the same error and accesses the service without issues.
How do you provide access to Drive for User A?

discussion.content: C is correct. Read this question carefully. Both users are in an OU with drive service disabled. The initial configuration was to leverage Access Groups as a way to distribute services for this workspace. User A is not part of that access group that enables the drive service but User B is.

according to this link [https://support.google.com/a/answer/182442?hl=en] you have 2 options to manage services for users, OUs and Groups, since they are on the same OU, they difference must be Groups, so C has to be correct
The answer cannot be D because Drive and Doc services is available via Basic License.
C is correct, keyword : access group
user A is in the same OU s USer B should be C

choices.A: Select User A in the Directory, and under the Apps section, check whether Drive and Docs is disabled. If so, enable it in the User record.
choices.D: Select User A in the Directory, and under the Licenses section, change their license from Basic to Business to add the Drive and Docs service.
choices.B: In Apps > G Suite > Drive and Docs, select the organizational unit the users are in and enable Drive for the organizational unit.
choices.C: In Apps > G Suite, determine the Group that has Drive and Docs enabled as a service. Add User A to this group.

questions.question_text:
Your company is deploying Chrome devices. You want to make sure the machine assigned to the employee can only be signed in to by that employee and no one else.
What two things should you do? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: A and E, Check "Sign-in restriction" here: https://support.google.com/chrome/a/answer/1375678?hl=en

choices.B: Enable a Device Policy of Sign In Screen and add the employee email address.
choices.D: Enable a User Policy of Multiple Sign In Access and add just the employee email address.
choices.A: Disable Guest Mode and Public Sessions.
choices.E: Enable a Device Policy of Restrict Sign In to List of Users, and add the employee email address.
choices.C: Enroll a 2-Factor hardware key on the device using the employee email address.
Transfer ownership of all Drive data using the file transfer ownership tool in the G Suite Admin console.
choices.A: Make the manager a delegate to the former employee's account.
choices.B: Copy the data from the former employee's My Drive to the manager's My Drive.
choices.D: Login as the user and add the manager to the file permissions using the "Is owner' privilege for all Drive files.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
It's C guys.

questions.question_text:
Your company policy requires that managers be provided access to Drive data once an employee leaves the company.
How should you grant this access?

After making a recent migration to G Suite, you updated your Google Cloud Directory Sync configuration to synchronize the global address list. Users are now seeing duplicate contacts in their global directory in G Suite. You need to resolve this issue.
What should you do?

choices.A: Train users to use G Suite's merge contacts feature.
choices.C: Update shared contact search rules to exclude internal users.
choices.D: Create a new global directory, and delete the original.
choices.B: Enable directory contact deduplication in the G Suite Admin panel.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
See Mr_JJ explanation below

choices.A: Enable "Suspicious login" rule - Other Recipients: CTO
choices.C: Enable "Email settings changed" rule - -Other Recipients: CTO
choices.B: Enable "Suspended user made active" rule - Other Recipients: CTO
choices.D: Enable "Suspended user made active" rule and select "Deliver to" Super Administrator(s)

questions.question_text:
The organization has conducted and completed Security Awareness Training (SAT) for all employees. As part of a new security policy, employees who did not complete the SAT have had their accounts suspended. The CTO has requested to be informed of any accounts that have been re-enabled to ensure no one is in violation of the new security policy.
What should you do?

discussion.content:
Should be B, need to inform CTO
CTO not necessarily Super Admin

Selected Answer: B
CTO must be informed when creating the Suspended user made activeâ€”A suspended user is made active by an admin Alert. Ref: https://support.google.com/a/answer/3230421?hl=en#zippy=%2Cuser-activity-alerts
